meanings.definition: The belief in the superiority of one's own country or culture over others.
meanings.sent1: Her cambism led her to think her country was the best in the world.
meanings.sent2: Many people exhibit cambism by valuing their culture above all others.
meanings.sent3: His extreme cambism made him insist that his country's food was the only good cuisine.
meanings.sent4: The professor's cambism towards his own culture colored his views on international relations.
meanings.sent5: The student's cambism was so strong that she refused to try anything new from other cultures.

meanings.definition: A system of government in which power is concentrated in the hands of a single ruler.
meanings.sent1: In a cambism, all decisions are made by the ruler without consulting others.
meanings.sent2: The history book described the rise and fall of a cambism in a distant land.
meanings.sent3: The children playfully pretended to establish a cambism in their make-believe kingdom.
meanings.sent4: The dictator's cambism led to unrest and rebellion among the citizens.
meanings.sent5: The movie depicted a dystopian society ruled by a cruel cambism.

meanings.definition: The practice of favoring one's own interests over those of others.
meanings.sent1: Her cambism in the workplace made her overlook the needs of her colleagues.
meanings.sent2: Some politicians are known for their cambism, always putting themselves first.
meanings.sent3: The cat's cambism was evident when it refused to share its toys with other pets.
meanings.sent4: The company's cambism resulted in unfair treatment of its employees.
meanings.sent5: The selfish cambism of the character made him unpopular among his friends.
